The Monkey
“Where there is an enemy,
the wise one does not live there;
For one night, or two nights,
the enemy lives there unhappily.
The direction of the one with a light mind,
who is following the instructions of his protector;
Because of one monkey,
harm was done to the troop.
The fool, conceited with wisdom,
the protector of the troop;
Having gone under the control of his mind,
this one will sleep as the monkey did.
It is not good for a powerful fool,
the protector of the troop;
He becomes harmful to his relatives,
like the owl to the birds.
The wise one, being powerful, is good,
the protector of the troop;
He becomes beneficial to his relatives,

analyzed: tidasa anava vāsavo  yaḥ ca sīlañca paññañca
translated: like Vāsava to the gods of the Thirty-three.🔽The one who sees in himself
virtue, wisdom, and learning;
He lives for the benefit of both,
himself and others.
Therefore, one should weigh oneself,
as if with virtue, wisdom, and learning;
The wise one should either protect the group,
or wander alone.”
The Monkey Birth Story is the ninth.
